title: Panel: Semantic Technologies for Big Data analaytics: Challenges and opportunities

And this is one of the main penetrators for the generation of large amounts of data.

30,000,000 pieces of content are shared on Facebook every month.

In global data generated per year, so 40% increase every year.
And 5% of these growth of growth is goes to the global idea.
Spending, which is a significant amount.

So this means this what this really means is that customers are there are maturing their expectations with respect to semantic web and big data, so they are becoming more realistic about what can be done or what cannot be done.
So for example, if we talk about the retail sector, we have several several customers in this sector who are precisely identifying these 4 letters on the on the right.
They are very interested in communicating better with customers and also with extracting as much information as possible from there from them.
So they're proposing omnichannel customer experience.
So this means communicating, then be a voice we are Mail via chat via social networks like Twitter or LinkedIn or whatever.
And they're also analyzing the social networks for position with the product with respect to these to these customers.
Examples of these applications are, for example, are personalized loyalty programs.
Other aspects were big data is important for this kind of customers are, for example merchandising.
They do observation of the prices that their competence offered to their customers.
They even analyze the Market Basket of customers in in in real stores.
So what you put in your in your in your basket they see what kind of things you put in there and make a profile of the customer.
And combine a lot of different kinds of data which they correlate.
Also important is marketing.
They do a lot of marketing stuff that they segment their users that consumers analyze campaigns, especially online.
Nowadays, very important with respect to social media.
And finally about supply chain.
These guys have a problem about logistics and they don't want to run out of stock.
This is one of the main reasons why they lose money and big data technologies and other technologies which are related like a sensor.
Networks sensor technologies are also very important for them in this in this regard.
This means that the.
There are opportunities, but these opportunities can become risks and actually can become timebombs if we don't react accordingly.
In this direction.
So I've identified here a few of them.
There are five opportunities or risks depending on how we react.
Which are access privacy, security, scalability, decay and the human factor?
So about access, if you take a look at the statistics, we see that idea staff spend about 70% of the time looking for information and only 30% doing actual work.
So this means that they really have a problem.
In order to access all the data that they need to do their daily work.
So we need the means to have more goal driven, problem oriented data selection.
And this is also important in order to have human data interfaces which are more effective and which also observe the different modalities of the data that we can have.
So we can have text.
But we can also have images, video, audio, all kind of data.
A multi channel.
Privacy.
If you can relate data, there are many things that can.
Surface about the about the customers and not all of these things can be made public or should be handled openly.
So privacy is a very important issue.
We are.
We are witnessing very notorious scandals related with the opening of private data.
So an imitation is a key issue here.
There are even well, I was going to say is starting to happen, but this is already going on for a long time.
Black market of personal data.
And this happened there.
Are there bad guys over there?
Hunting for your data and try to and trying to get money out of it.
Security.
Well.
Many people say that data is the new oil, but I would say that data is a new currency.
And the new currency data needs to be kept under custody.
Needs to be invested wisely and.
Needs to be kept safe.
So many people in the security community are talking about establishing firewalls and security intelligence around our big data infrastructure.
So it's important to know who's accessing the data, what data were, when, what are they doing with it?
This is also related with the provenance of data and what things happen about it.
Scalability.

Already already was mentioned in A and an extensive list of things that are related to this, but I wanted to reflect on the fact that at Regina's data, as the kind of data that we are managing in this environment has different and different storage and preservation needs both in time and in space, it is not the same thing to store.
Video, or Dyna storing text in turmoil in terms of space, are doing a data intensive work for a customer that requires the data to be accessible here or in 20 years in the future.
The next potential opportunity or time bomb, depending on how we want to approach it, is the decay of the data.
It can potentially decay.
We are enabling data or use an aggregation.
A lot of the applications that we are doing nowadays depend on data that we use from external sources, and these sources are not under our control.

So if we want to link to these sources and do effective applications that keep safe and stable in the future, we need to keep track and we need to monitor the health of datasets that we are that we are using.

So concepts like data availability, Accessibility, availability and change will become more and more important, and this is also this also depends on the type of data that we are using, can be discreet discrete data like the datasets that we have nowadays in the in the link open data cloud or can be continuous data coming from streams and this different natures has an impact in the treatment of decay.
And finally, the human factor mark already pointed out there is a lack of data.
Save your stuff.
For example, the same McKinsey report mentions that there are 150,000 positions needed and 100 and 1/2 million data saving managers.

So this is a lot of people and something which is especially worrying is that if you talk to companies to corporations, no matter if they are big or small, many of them don't even have a data management plan.
And this means that, well, there's a lot of infrastructure.
There's a lot of potential, but it is not clear how to administer it wisely.
And that's it.
From my side.
Thank you very much.
